sp.p: The Peruvian leader?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I was so yesterday—To-day, the Spaniards captive.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And friendship to Alonzo moved thee to this act?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo is my friend—I am prepared to die for him. Yet is the cause a motive stronger far than friendship.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: One only passion else could urge such generous rashness.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And that is—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Love?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: True!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Gallant!—ingenius Rolla!—Know that my purpose here was thine; and were I to save thy friend—

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: How!—a woman bless'd with gentleness and courage, and vet not Cora!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Does Rolla think so meanly of all female hearts?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Not so—you are worse and better than we are!—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: To save thee, Rolla, from the tyrant's vengeance—restore thee to thy native land—and thy native land to peace—would'st thou not rank Elvira with the good?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: To judge the action, I must know the means.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Take this dagger.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: How to be used?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I will conduct thee to the tent where fell Pizarro sleeps—That scourge of innocence—the terror of thy race—the fiend, that desolates thy afflicted country.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Have you not been injured by Pizarro?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Deeply as scorn and insult can infuse their deadly venom.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And you ask that I shall murder him in his sleep!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Would he not have murder'd Alonzo in chains? he that sleeps and he that's bound, are equally defenceless. Hear me, Rolla—so may I prosper in this perilous act as, searching my full heart, I have put by all rancorous motive of private vengeance there, and feel that I advance to my dread purpose in the cause of human nature, and at the call of sacred justice.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: The God of justice sanctifies no evil as a step towards good. Great actions cannot be atchieved by wicked means.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Then. Peruvian! since thou dost feel so coldly for thy country's wrongs, this hand, tho' it revolt my soul, shall strike the blow.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Then is thy destruction certain, and for Peru thou peris • est!—Give me the dagger!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Now follow me:—but first—and dreadful to the hart 〈◊〉 —you must strike down the guard.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: The soldier who was on duty here?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes, him—else, seeing thee, the alarm will be instant.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And I must stab that soldier as I pass? Take back thy dagger.

sp.speaker: Eto.
sp.p: Rolla!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: That soldier, mark me, is a man—All are not men that bear the human form. He refus'd my prayers—refus'd my gold—denying to admit—till his own feelings 〈◊〉 him. For my nations safty, I would not harm that man!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Then he must be with us—I will answer for his safety.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Be that plainly understood between us;—for whate'er betide our enterprize, I will not risk a hair of that man's head, to save my heart strings from consuming fire.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: The inside of Pizarro's Tent.—Pizarro on a Couch, in disturbed sleep.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (in his sleep) No mercy, traitor.—Now at his heart!—Stand off there, you—Let me see him bleed!—Ha! ha! ha!—Let me hear that groan again.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: There!—NOw, lose not a moment.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: You must leave me now. This scene of blood fits not a woman's presence.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: But a moment's pause may—

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Go!—Retire to your own tent—and return not here—I will come to you—Be thou not known in this business, I implore you!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I will withdraw the guard that waits.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Now have I in my power the accurs'd destroyer of my country's peace: yet tranquilly he rests.—God!—can this man sleep?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (In his sleep.) Away! Away!—Hideous fiends!—Tear not my bosom thus!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: No:—I was in error—the balm of sweet repose he never more can know. Look here ambitious fools!—Ye, by whose inhuman pride, the bleeding sacrifice of nations is held as nothing—behold the rest of the guilty! He is at my mercy—and one blow!—No!—my heart and hand refuse the act: Rolla cannot be an assasin!—You Elvira must be saved!(Approaches the Couch.) Pizarro! awake!—

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (Starts up) Who?—Guard!—

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Speak not—another word is thy death—Call not for aid!—this arm will be swifter than thy guard.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What art thou? and what is thy will?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I am thine enemy! Peruvian Rolla! Thy death is not my will, or I could have slain thee sleeping.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Speak, what else?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p:
Now thou art at my mercy—answer me!—Did
a Peruvian ever yet wrong or injure thee, or any of thy nation: didst thou, or any of thy nation, ever yet shew mercy to a Peruvian in your power? Now shalt thou feel—and if thou hast a heart, thou • t feel it keenly!—a Peruvian's vengeance! (Drops the dagger at his feet) There!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Is it possible! (Walks aside confounded.)

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Can Pizarro be surprised at this? I thought forgiveness of injuries had been the Christian's precept—Thou seest, at least it is the Peruvian's practice.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rolla—thou hast indeed surpris'd subdu'd me. (Walks again aside as in irresolute thought.)

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Is it done? Is he dead? (Sees Pizarro) How!—still living! Then I am lost! And for you, wretched Peruvians! mercy is no more!—Oh! Rolla! treacherous, or cowardly?—

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: How can it be, that—

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Away! Elvira speaks she knows not what! Leave me (to Elvira) I conjure you, with Pizarro.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How!—Rolla, do'st thou think I shall retract—or that I meanly will deny, that in thy hand I plac'd a poignard to be plung'd into that tyrant's heart? No:—my sole regret is, that I trusted to thy weakness, and did not strike the blow myself.—Too soon thou'lt learn that mercy to that man is direct cruelty to thy race!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Guard! Quick! a guard to seize this frantic woman.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
Yes, a guard! I call them too! And soon I know they lead me to my death. But think not, Pizarro, the fury of thy flashing eyes shall awe me for a moment—Nor think that woman's anger, or the feelings of 〈◊〉 injur'd heart, prompted me to this design—No! Ha •• I been only influenc'd so—thus failing, shame and remorse would weigh me down. But tho' defeated and destroyed as now I am, such is the greatness of the cause that urged me, I shall perish glorying in the attempt, and my last breath of life shall speak the proud avowal of my purpose—to have rescued millions of innocens from the blood-thirsty
tyranny of ONE—by ridding the insulted world of THEE.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Had the act been noble as the motive—Rolla would not have shrunk from its performance.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Seize this discover'd fiend, who sought to kill your leader.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Touch me not, at the peril of your souls;—I am your prisoner, and will follow you.—But thou, their triumphant leader, shalt hear me. Yet, first—for thee Rolla, accept my forgiveness: even had I been the victim of thy nobleness of heart, I should have admired thee for it—But 'twas myself provok'd my doom—thou would'st have shielded me.—Let not thy contempt follow me to the grave. Didst thou but know the spell-like arts by which this hypocrite first undermin'd the virtue of a guileless heart! how, even in the pious sanctuary wherein I dwelt, by corruption and fraud, he practis'd upon those in whom I most confided—till my distemper'd fancy led me, step by step, into the 〈◊〉 of guilt— 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Why am I not obey'd?—Tear her hence!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: 'Tis past—but didst thou know my story, Rolla, thou would'st pity me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: From my soul I pity thee!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Villains! drag her to the dungeon!—prepare the torture instantly.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
Soldiers—but a moment more—'Tis to applaud your general—It is to tell the astonish'd world, that, for once, Pizarro's sentence is an act of justice: yes, rack me with the sharpest tortures that ever agoniz'd the human frame; It will be justice. Yes—bid the minions—wr • neh forth the sinews of those arms that have caress'd and—ever have defended thee! Bid them, pour burning metal into the bleeding cases of those eyes, that so oft, oh God!—have hung with love and homage on thy looks—then approach me bound on the abhorted wheel—there glut thy savage eyes with the convuls'd spasms of that dishonor'd bosom, which was once thy 〈◊〉 ! Yet, will I bear it all! And when thou shalt bid them tear me to death, hoping that thy unshrinking
ears may at last be feasted with the music of my cries, I will not utter one shriek or groan—but to the last gasp, my body's patience shall deride vengeance, as my soul defies thy power.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (Endeavouring to conceal his agitation.) Hear'st thou the wretch whose hands were even now prepared for murder?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Yes! And if her accusation's false, thou wilt not shrink from hearing her: if true, thy barbarity cannot make her suffer the pangs thy conscience will inflict on thee

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And now, farewell, world!—Rolla farewell!—Farewell thou condemn'd of heaven!—(To Pizarro)—for repentance and remorse, I know, will never touch thy heart.—We shall meet again.—Ha! be it thy horror here, to know that we shall meet hereafter!—And when thy parting hour approaches—hark to the knell, whose dreadful beat will strike to thy despairing soul. Then, will vibrate to thy ear the curses of the cloister'd saint from whom you stole me. Then the last shrieks which burst from my mother's breaking heart, as she died, appealing to her God against the seducer of her child! Then the blood-stifled groan of my murder'd brother—murdered by thee, fell monster!—seeking atonement for his sisters ruin'd honour.—I hear them now To me, the recollection's madness!—At such an hour,—what will it be to thee?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: A moment's more delay, and at the peril of your lives—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I have spoken—and the last mortal frailty of my heart is past.—And now, with an updaunted spirit, and unshaken firmness, I go to meet my destiny. That I could not live nobly, has been PIZARRO'S ACT. That I will die nobly, shall be my OWN.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rolla, I would not thou, a warrior valiant and renown'd, should credit the vile tales of this frantic woman, The cause of all this fury—O! a wanton passion for the rebel youth Alonzo, now my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Alonzo is not now thy prisoner.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I came to rescue him—to deceive his guard—I have succeeded; I remain thy prisoner.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Alonzo fled!—Is then the vengeance dearest to my heart never to he gratified?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Dismiss such passions from thy heart; then thou'lt consult its peace.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: I can face all enemies that dare confront me—I cannot war against my nature.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Then Pizarro, ask not to be deem'd a hero—to triumph o'er ourselves is the only conquest, where fortune makes no claim. In battle, chance may snatch the laurel from thee, or chance may place it on thy brow—but in a contest with yourself, be resolute, and the virtuous impulse must be the victor.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Peruvian! thou shalt not find me to thee ungrateful, or ungenerous—return to your countrymen—you are at liberty.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thou do'st act in this as honor and duty bid thee.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: I cannot but admire thee, Rolla; I would we might be friends.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Farewell.—Pity Elvira!—become the friend of virtue—and thou wilt be mine.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Ambition! tell me what is the phantom I have followed? where is the one delight which it has made my own? my fame is the mark of envy—my love the dupe of treachery—my glory eclips'd by the boy I taught—my revenge defeated and rebuked by the rude honor of a savage foe—before whose native dignity of soul I have sunk confounded and subdued—and I have suffered him to escape! The enemy's strength was in my power.—Guards! (going) hold, Pizarro, hast thou not pledged thy faith: damnation!—yet he is but a heathen, and our priests—away, away! damned sophistry!—the faith of heroes ever was the same.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: An open place near the Peruvian camp.

sp.speaker: Ata,
sp.p: Every thing around me is dreary and silent.—The sensations which succeed a victory resemble those which succeed a fever. We have scarcely strength enough to rejoice. Our smiles swim in tears—the triumph is expressed in sighs. Conquest is always dearly bought. Historians tell us how many are slain, but never let us know how many are made wretched. The arrow, which hits one heart, sometimes inflicts a hundred wounds. Oh! I would give all my conquests for one harvest festival.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The herald has returned without consolation.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Is Alonza dead?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No, but the Spaniards have refused the ransom. Your treasures, said the haughty robbers, belong to us, and soon we shall be your masters. Justice dwells in our strength.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: What! not humbled yet. Do these address, then, which are hissing round my throne, for ever grow again? where is Cora?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: She fled with her child but none knows whither. The army is alarmed, for Rolla too has disappeared.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Rolla! Impossible! He forsake me, when surrounded my misfortune and danger! oh, heavens! Is there no one who wishes to obtain my dignity! I will exchange my situation for that of the meanest of my realm.

div.stage: Enter ALONZO, in the Monk's habit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do I behold my king again?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Alonzo, is it you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Where is my wife?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: How did you escape?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: By half a miracle.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Speak!—tell me all.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Who but Rolla could, by friendship urged, make so great a sacrifice? who but Rolla could muffle himself in this mantle, and force his way even to my prison? He it was, that broke my chains to h • ng them on himself.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Rolla in our enemy's power! alas! you wound me again.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Throwing off the monks habit.) Give me a sword, and five hundred of your boldest warsiors, that I may hasten to release him.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Shall I risk in you my last support?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: The enemy is dismayed; and the camp on the right side but ill defended. Pizarro has made himself detested by his cruelties. His soldiers murmur; let them not have time to reflect. Another victory, and we drive them into the ocean.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Accompany me, I will myself examine where it will be most proper to attack them.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do not expose yourself to danger, you are our king.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: When the children are surrounded with danger, the father should exert himself.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Let me first embrace my dearest Cora.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: (with confusion.) Cora!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Her sufferings must have been great.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: They have indeed.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I will return to you in a few moments.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Where will you seek her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (alarmed) Is she not here?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Her anxiety drove her from us.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: I know not. To the mountains, perhaps where her father dwells.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Heavens! what a chillness runs through my veins!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: She was seen running about the field of battle, calling for Alonzo till it was dark.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then she disappeared in the woods.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The woods! where Spanish soldiers are continually—Cora! Cora! (Going.)

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Alonzo! whither are you going!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Wherever error and despair may lead me. Good Inca, you are in safety. The vanquished foe dare not attack you. Oh you who does protect the rights of all your subjects, respect, the rights of nature, my wife, my child, my all is 〈◊〉 , Release me from my duty as a leader, that I may fulfil the duties of a husband, and go in search of Cora.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: I deeply feel your agony, go, but forget not Rolla.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Cora!—Rolla!—what guardian angel will direct my steps.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p:
(to the Courtier.) Give me your sword, (the Courtier presents I •
) 〈◊〉 (tries to raise it but his arm sinks) I cannot, poor monarch! what avail reason and courage of the limbs refuse their office.

div.head: SCENE. I.
div.stage: A thick Forest—in the back ground a Hut almost covered by Boughs of Trees—A dreadful storm, with Thunder and Lightning—CORA has covered her Child on a Bed of Leaves and Moss—Her whole appearance is wild and distracted.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: O NATURE! thou has 〈◊〉 the strength of love. My anxious spirit is untired in its march—my wearied, shivering frame, sinks under it. And, 〈◊〉 thee, my boy—when faint beneath thy lovely burthen, could I refuse to give thy slumbers that poor bed of rest! O my child! were I assured thy father breathes no more, how quickly would I • ay me down by thy dear side; but down—down for ever. (Thunder and lightning). I ask thee not, unpitying storm! to abate thy rage, in mercy to poor Cora's misery; nor while thy thunders spare his slumbers will I disturb my sleeping cherub. Tho' Heaven knows I wish to hear the 〈◊〉 of life, and feel that life is near me. But I will 〈◊〉 all while what I have of reason holds. (Thunder and lightning.) Still, still, implacable! unfeeling settlements! yet still dost thou sleep, my smiling innocent O, death! when wilt thou grant to this babe's mother such repose? Sure I may shield thee better from the storm; my veil may—

div.p: While she is wrapping her mantle and her veil over him, ALONZO'S voice is heard a great distance.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Cora!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Hah!!! (Rises.)

sp.speaker: Al. (Again)
sp.p: Cora!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: O, my heart! Sweet Heaven deceive me not!—Is it not Alonzo's voice?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Nearer) Cora!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: It is—it is Alonzo!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Nearer still) Cora my beloved!—

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Alonzo!—Here!—Here!—Alonzo!

sp.speaker: 1st Sol.
sp.p: I tell you we are near our out-posts, and the word we heard just now was the countersign.

sp.speaker: 2d sol.
sp.p: Well, in • our escape from the enemy, to have discovered their secret passage thro' the rocks, will prove a lucky chance to us—Pizarro will reward us.

sp.speaker: 1st Sol.
sp.p: This way—The sun, though clouded, is on our left. (Perceives the Child.) What have we here?—A child!—as I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: 2d Sol.
sp.p: 'Tis a sweet 〈◊〉 babe. Now would it be a great charity to take this infant from its pagan mother's power.

sp.speaker: 1st Sol.
sp.p: It would so.—I have one at home shall play with it.—Come along.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Speaking without) This way, dear Alonzo, Now I am 〈◊〉 —there—there—under that tree. Was it possible the instinct of a mother's heart could mistake the spirit. Now will you look at him as he sleeps, or shall I bring 〈◊〉 waking with his full blue laughing eyes to welcome 〈◊〉 at once—Yes—yes—stand thou there—I'll snatch 〈◊〉 from his rosy slumber, blushing like the perfume 〈◊〉 .

p.hi: She runs up to the spot, and, finding only the 〈◊〉 and veil, which she tears from the ground, 〈◊〉 the child gone, (shrieks) and stands in speechless 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Running to her) Cora!—my heart's beloved!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: He is gone!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Eternal God!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: He is gone!—my child! my child!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Dashing herself on the spat) Here!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Be calm, beloved Cora—he has wak'd, and accept to a little distance—we shall find him—are you assured this was the spot you left him in?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Did not these hands make that bed, and shelter for him?—and is not this the veil that covered him?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Here is a hut yet unobserved.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Ha! Yes, yes! therelives the savage that has rob'd me of my child—(Beats at the door exclaiming) Give me back my child—restore to me my boy!

div.stage: Enter LAS CASSAS from the Hut

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: Who calls me from my wretched solitude?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Give me back my child! (Goes into the hut and calls) Fernando!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Almighty powers! do my eyes deceive me! Las Casas!!!

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: Alonzo,—my belov'd young friend!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My rever'd instructor. (Embracing.)

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Returned.) Will you embrace 〈◊〉 man before he restores my boy?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Alas, my friend—in what a moment of misery do we meet!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Yet his look is goodness and humanity.—Good old man, have compassion on a wretched mother—and I will be your servant while I live.—But do not, for pity's sake—do not say, you have him not—do not say you have not seen him.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: She is my wife.—Just rescued from the Spanish prison, I learn'd she had fled to this wild forest—hearing my voice, she left the child, and flew to 〈◊〉 me—he was left sleeping under yonder tree.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: How! did you leave him?—(Cora returns.)

sp.speaker: Cora,
sp.p: O, you are right!—right!—unnatural, mother, that I was—I left my child—I forsook my 〈◊〉 —but I will fly to the earth's brink, but I will find him. I have left my darling infant, and the vengeance of the gods pursue me.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: Oh that I could console you!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Help me to bear this load of 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Raving) Look at that speckled snake!—look how it twines round the child's body!—now it hisses!—now it stings his heart!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dearest Cora, compose yourself.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
Do you see that cruel condor hovering in the air. Now it shoots down—darts its talons into the defenceless infant. There a blood thirsty tyger lies in
ambush, waiting for its prey!—now it springs from the thicket!—see how it tears him to pieces! (Falls) Help! help!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Kneeling by her side.) My wife! my son!

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: Images of misery pursue me even to this solitude!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Console us, Oh, Las-Casas, my instructor, my benefactor, do not forsake us at this sorrowful hour.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: I will remain with you, but we are near the Spanish camp, fly to your friends. I will accompany you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But how shall we convey this wretched being?

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: Raise her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come, dearest Cora—let us go.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Go! whither?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To our friends.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: I quit this place—this place where my Fernando died?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: We are so near the enemy's camp.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: How cruel thou art! shall I even not collect my infant's bones?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your father and brother are arrived.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: I have neither father nor brother. I only had a child.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: We will go in search of it.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Suddenly springing up) Go in search of it? where! where!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: This old man will assist us.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Yes, yes good old man! assist us to seek our child.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: Willingly, dear Cora, if you will collect yourself.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Have you any children?

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Then I may forgive the expression. Give me back my child—then you will learn to know the composure of a mother.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Forgive me, Las-Casas, I must follow her: for at night, I attempt brave Rolla's rescue.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: I will not leave you, Alonzo—you must try to lead her to the right—that way lies your camp—Wait not my infirm steps,—I follow you, my friend.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: The Out Post of the Spanish Camp.—The back ground wild and rocky, with a Torrent falling down the Precipice, over which a Bridge is formed by a felled Tree. Trumpets sound without.

sp.speaker: Almagro.
sp.p: (Without.) Bear him along—his story must be false.(Entering.)

div.stage: ROLLA (in Chains) brought in by Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: False!—Rolla, utter falsehood!—I would I had thee in a desart with thy troop around thee;—and I, but with my sword in this unshackled hand!—(Trumpets without.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Is it to be credited that Rolla, the renown'd Peruvian hero—should be detected like a spy, skulking thro' our camp?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Skulking!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: But answer to the general—he is here.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What do I see! Rolla!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: O! to your surprise, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And bound too!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: So fast, you need'st not fear approaching me.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: The guards surpris'd him, passing our out-post.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Release him instantly.—Believe me, I regret this insult.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: You feel then as you ought.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Nor can I brook to see a warrior of Rolla's fame disarm'd—Accept this, tho' it has been thy enemy's. (Gives a sword.) The Spaniards know the courtesy that's due to valour.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: And the Peruvian, how to forget offence.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: May not Rolla and Pizarro cease to be foes?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: When the sea divides us!—

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p:
How if we were to be united by mutual interest?
my claim to Quito's throne I will renounce. Submit to the Spanish sceptre, acknowledge the christian faith, and I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Generous indeed!

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: The protection of a mighty monarch depends on Pizarro's friendship, and this Pizarro makes thee an offer of his hand.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Rolla never was a traitor.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Thou wilt alone avert misfortune from thy native land.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I owe my life but not my honor, to my native land.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: It is only removing a weak king from a station for which he was not formed.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Ataliba weak!—but were he weak, a king who makes his people happy, is, through their affection, strong.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Follow thy own counsel.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: My conscience has long since decided.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rejected friendship rages as fiercely as rejected love.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Ha! that is the point at which I see you aim. Take off the mask.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (Subduing his fury.) Rolla, thou mistak'st me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: May I now depart?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: (After a struggle) Freely.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Will nothing intercept my way.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Nothing unless repentance bring thee back.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thanks to the gods, I have never yet repented any thing.

div.stage: Enter DAVILLA and Soldiers, with the Child

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Here are two soldiers, captived yesterday, who have escap'd from the Peruvian hold,—and by the secret way we have so long endeavoured to discover.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Silence;—imprudent!—Seest thou not?—(Pointing to Rolla)

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: In their way they found a Peruvian child, who seems—

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: What is the imp to me?—Bid them toss it into the sea.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Gracious heaven! it is Alonzo's child!—give it to me.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Ha! Alonzo's child!—Welcome, thou pretty hostage.—Now Alonzo is again my prisoner!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Thou wilt not keep the infant from its mother?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Will I not!—What, when I shall meet Alonzo in the heat of the victorious fight—think'st thou I shall not have a check upon the valour of his heart, when he is reminded that a word of mine is this child's death?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: My vengeance has a long arrear of hate to settle with Alonzo!—and this pledge may help to settle the account,

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Man! Man!—Art thou a man?—Could'st thou hurt that innocent!—By Heaven! it is smiling in thy face.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Figure to thyself this little head stuck on a lance's point—then fancy Alonzo, with uplifted sword, running against us, bearing all before him like a rapid stream, which nothing can arrest but a—child's head. Ha! I see him there standing petrified.—Down sinks his sword, and with horror in his countenance, he surveys the bloody banner, from which the drops are still trickling down the lance. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Dost thou call thyself a human being?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: And then at his arrival at home, when his anxious wife throws her white arms around his neck, and with her silken hair wipes off the drops of blood—"Stop," he will say "you think this to be the enemy's blood."—Ha! ha! ha! it's the blood of your infant."

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Look at the boy's sweet smiles. Could'st thou murder this innocent?

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Could'st thou kill a pigeon?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Be contented with a ransom, I will send this infant's weight in silver.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Convert it into a monument, to be erected on his grave.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Pizarro, I have spared your life. Grant me in return this infant's life.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Tell me, does it resemble Cora?

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p:
Pizarro! thou hast set my heart on fire—If thou do'st harm that child—think not his blood will sink into
the barren sand—No!—faithful to the eager hope that now trembles in his indignat heart—'twill rise to the common God of nature and humanity, and cry aloud for vengeance on it's accurs'd destroyer's head.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Be that peril mine.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (Throwing himself at his feet) Behold me at thy feet—Me, Rolla!—Me, the preserver of thy life!—Me, that have never yet bent or bow'd before created man!—In humble agony I sue to you—prostrate I implore you—but spare that child, and I will be your slave.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Rolla! still art thou free to go—this boy remains with me.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: Then was this sword Heaven's gift, not thine! (Seizes the Child)—Who moves one step to follow me, dies upon the spot.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Pursue him instantly—but spare his life (Exeunt Almagro and soldiers.) With what fury he defends himself!—Ha!—he fells them to the ground—and now—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Three of your brave soldiers are already victims to your command to spare this madman's life; and if he once gains the thicket—

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Spare him no longer (Exit Almagro.) Their guns must reach him—he'll yet escape—holloa to those horse—the Peruvian sees them—and now he turns among the rocks—then is his retreat cut off.

div.p: (Rolla crosses the wooden bridge over the cataract, pursued by the soldiers—they fire at him—a shot strikes him—Pizarro exclaims—

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Now! quick! quick! seize the child!—

div.p: (Rolla tears from the rock the tree which supports the bridge, and retreats by the back ground, bearing off the child.)

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: By hell! he has escap'd!—and with the child unhurt.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: No—he bears his death with him—Believe me, I saw him struck upon the side.

sp.speaker: Piz.
sp.p: Shot!—Brave man—worthy of a nobler Heath!—I might have won thy friendship—yes, by heaven I admire him—yet I am his murderer! away!—give me a thousand men like him, and I will conquer the world!

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: An open place near the Peruvian Camp.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: The storm is over, the enemy quiet, and my troops are buried in profound sleep. Not a breath of air is murmuring in the trees. All is silent around me—but not here—(pointing to his heart.) And why not here?—Did I not draw the sword for God and my country? why am I to be pursued by the spectres of the slain? Why am I to be tormented by the groans of the dying?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: Whither am I going? where is my child's grave (Seeing the king) ha! thou son of the sun, restore to me my child.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Cora, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: From my infants grave—there under the earth—there it is cold and damp. (shudders) I shiver!

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Horrible!

div.stage: Enter ALONZO and LAS-CASAS, in search of CORA.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Wretched Cora! whether does thy phrenzy lead thee?

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p:
Peace Alonzo. There stands the sun of the gods. The sun is his father. Let him but say a word, and the grave will open, and throw out its prey (Embraces
his knees) oh my king, speak this one powerful word! have pity on a distracted mother's anguish.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Ye gods! what means this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: She has lost her infant.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Poor mother, I cannot receive you. Alas! I am 〈◊〉 king.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You cannot! who can help me then? To whom have the gods entrusted our existence? It was thee who led the Peruvians to battle—it was my Alonzo that fought for thee—dost thou refuse me the only reward for all his courage—the life of a child, who will hereafter fight for thee?

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Annihilate me ye gods! I cannot bear this.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Hastily rising) Tyrant who cannot be moved either by my prayers or by my anguish, has not yet blood enough been split to satisfy thy rank ambition? Behold on each of thy diamonds hangs a drop of blood. Art thou 〈◊〉 satisfied—must an infant be torn from a mother's breast to cast it to the beasts of prey?—What is thy diadem to me? what cares a mother for Quito's throne? Come hither her all ye, whom victory has robbed of children! assist me to curse this barbarian and let the cries of our misery rise with his shouts of joy to heaven. Oh, if he does but feel for ever the distresses of one wretched mother, his punishment will be great. (Sinks breathless to the ground.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Clasping her in his arms)—To Ataliba.) Excuse the parenzy of a mother.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: (Wiping away a tear) Alas! my throne can bestow no compensation for this tear.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Smiling) Alonzo, my breast is painful. Reach me the child. (Exhausted) Oh, cruel Alonzo; you see me dying, and will not let me feel once more the rapture of embracing my child.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Alas! this is more horrid than her phrenzy. Continue raging, poor helpless mother! thou no longer hast a child.

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Smiling) Thou no longer hast a child.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: and Alon. Rolla! Rolla!

div.stage: Enter ROLLA Wounded, in his right hand the bloody sword, on his left arm CORA'S Child.

sp.speaker: Ata.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: (Sinks on his knees before Cora exclaiming) Cora, thy infant!

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: My child—covered with blood!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: It is my blood (Giving her the child.)

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Pressing it to her breast) My infant! Rolla!

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: I loved thee! thou hast done me injustice! I can do no more—(Sinking.)

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: (Kneeling down by him) Rolla! thou diest!—

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.p: For Cora—and thee!—(Dies.)

sp.speaker: Cora.
sp.p: (Throwing herself down by the body) O! has ever mortal loved like this man? (To the child) Boy, thou art dearly purchased!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: (Starting up) Las-Casas! help me to believe in God.

sp.speaker: Las-C.
sp.p: His ways are obscure. Pray and be humble.
